content.text: Distinguish between _scalar_ quantities and _vector_ quantities
In the following list, underline **all** the scalar quantities
acceleration force kinetic energy mass power weight
calculate the time to fall \(15\mathrm{m}\),
calculate the magnitude of the resultant velocity after falling \(15 \text{m}\),
describe the difference between the displacement of the stone and the distance that it travels
A stone is thrown with a horizontal velocity of \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\) from the top of a cliff \(15 \text{m}\) high. The path of the stone is shown in Fig. 1.1
Air resistance is negligible
For this stone,
Show that the SI base units of the quantity \(D\) are \(\mathsf{kgm}^{- 1}\mathsf{s}^{- 1}\)

A raindrop of radius \(1.5 \text{mm}\) falls vertically in air at a velocity of \(3.7 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The value of \(D\) for air is \(6.6 \times 10^{-4} \text{kg m}^{-1} \text{s}^{-1}\). The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg m}^{-3}\)
Calculate
1. the magnitude of the frictional force \(F,\)
2. the acceleration of the raindrop
acceleration =   .........  \(\text{ms}^{-2}\)
A sphere of radius \(R\) is moving through a fluid with constant speed \(v.\) There is a frictional force \(F\) acting on the sphere, which is given by the expression
where \(D\) depends on the fluid
State the variation with time of the acceleration of the raindrop
A second raindrop has a radius that is smaller than that given in **(a)**. On Fig. 2.1, sketch the variation of speed with time for this second raindrop.
The variation with time \(t\) of the speed \(v\) of the raindrop in **(a)** is shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1
Explain what is meant by work done
Define power
<label>
Calculate the kinetic energy, in kJ, of the carriage and passengers as they travel towards the slope
kinetic energy =   .........  kJ
Show that the gain in potential energy of the carriage and passengers is \(24 \text{kJ}\)
Calculate the work done against the resistive force as the carriage moves up the slope
For
Examiner's
Use
work done =   .........  kJ
Use your answer in (iii) to calculate the resistive force acting against the carriage as it moves up the slope
resistive force =   .........  N
Fig. 3.1 shows part of a fairground ride with a carriage on rails

The carriage and passengers have a total mass of \(600\mathrm{kg}.\) The carriage is travelling at a speed of \(9.5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) towards a slope inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The carriage comes to rest after travelling up the slope to a vertical height of \(4.1\mathrm{m}\)
Describe, with the aid of a diagram, the apparatus that could be used
For
Examiner's
Use
Describe the method used to obtain the required measurements
Describe how the measurements taken can be used to determine the Young modulus
A student measures the Young modulus of a metal in the form of a wire
electromotive force (e.m.f.),
internal resistance
For a cell, explain the terms
Apply Kirchhoff's second law to calculate the current in the circuit
current =   .........  A
Calculate the power transformed by battery B
Calculate the total energy lost per second in resistor R and the internal resistances
energy lost per second =   .........  \(Js^{-1}\)
The circuit of Fig. 5.1 shows two batteries A and B and a resistor R connected in series
Battery A has an e.m.f. of 3.0V and an internal resistance of \(0.10\Omega\). Battery B has an e.m.f. of 12V and an internal resistance of \(0.20\Omega\). Resistor R has a resistance of \(3.3\Omega\)
The circuit of Fig. 5.1 may be used to store energy in battery A. Suggest how your answers in (b) support this statement
Explain why one laser and two slits are used, instead of two lasers, to produce a visible fringe pattern on the screen
State the phase difference between the waves that meet at
1. State the principle of superposition
2. Use the principle of superposition to explain the dark fringe at P
Apparatus used to produce interference fringes is shown in Fig. 6.1. The apparatus is not drawn to scale

Laser light is incident on two slits. The laser provides light of a single wavelength. The light from the two slits produces a fringe pattern on the screen. A bright fringe is produced at C and the next bright fringe is at B. A dark fringe is produced at P
In Fig. 6.1 the distance from the two slits to the screen is \(1.8 \text{m}\). The distance CP is \(2.3 \text{mm}\) and the distance between the slits is \(0.25 \text{mm}\)
Calculate the wavelength of the light provided by the laser
wavelength =   .........  nm
